questions.question: Question 1: What type of immunity is being conferred to a neonate receiving the BCG vaccine?
questions.explanation:
The immunity conferred to a neonate receiving the BCG vaccine is artificial active immunity, as it 
involves administering a live attenuated vaccine form of Mycobacterium bovis to stimulate an 
adaptive immune response and develop antibodies, establishing long-term immunity. Types of adaptive immunity: • Natural active immunity: It results from either a clinical or an inapparent infection by a microbe. • Artificial active immunity: It is the resistance induced by vaccines which are preparations of 
killed or attenuated microorganisms or their products. • Natural passive immunity: It is the immunity passively transferred from mother to baby. In 
human infants, maternal antibodies are transmitted predominantly through the placenta, while in 
animals such as pigs, the transfer of antibodies occurs mainly through the colostrum. • Artificial passive immunity: It is the resistance passively transferred to a recipient by the 
administration of antibodies. Hyperimmune sera of animal or human origin, convalescent sera, 
and pooled human immunoglobulin are used for this purpose. • Combined immunization: A combination of the active and passive methods of immunization is 
used. Examples of the above types of immunity: Note: Adoptive immunity is immunity in which immunologically competent lymphocytes are 
injected. The transfer factor is composed of these immunologically competent lymphocytes. It can 
passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against those antigens to which the donor is sensitive. Immunity

Question 2: A 33-year-old with a large dirty wound on his knee and abrasions on his palms presents to the 
casualty. He does not remember the last time he received a TT injection and was thus given 
tetanus immunoglobulin. Which of the following is false about this type of immunity?
questions.explanation:
Giving pre-formed immunoglobulin (e.g. Tetanus immunoglobulin) directly is an example of 
passive immunity, which is not long-lasting. The differentiating features between active and passive immunity: Negative phase: It is the time period during which the level of measurable immunity is lower than 
it was before the antigenic stimulus. This is because the antigen combines with any pre-existing 
antibody and lowers its level in circulation. It is seen at the beginning of the active immune 
response. Secondary type response: If an individual who has been actively immunized against an antigen 
experiences the same antigen subsequently, the immune response occurs more quickly and 
abundantly than during the first encounter. Active Immunity

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis was administered transfer factor as 
treatment. What type of immunity does this result in?
questions.explanation:
Adoptive immunity occurs when transfer factor is given. Transfer factor is composed of an extract of immunologically competent lymphocytes such as T 
lymphocytes, NK cells, macrophages, or B cells. It has the ability to passively transfer 
cell-mediated immunity against antigens to which the donor is sensitive. It has been attempted in the treatment of lepromatous leprosy and chronic mucocutaneous 
candidiasis.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not a pattern recognition receptor?
questions.explanation:
Bone morphogenetic protein-like receptors are not pattern-recognition receptors. Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) are essential for the innate immune system. They identify 
pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) common to classes of microbes and trigger 
immune responses. These receptors can be found on the cell surface, detecting extracellular 
pathogens, or within the endosomes and cellular matrix, detecting intracellular invading viruses. PRRs activate pro-inflammatory pathways, promote phagocytosis in cells like macrophages, 
neutrophils and dendritic cells, and may act as secreted proteins binding directly to pathogens. 
Based on the localization and functional characteristics, PRRs are classified as: • Membrane-bound PRRs: • Toll-like receptors (TLR)- detect microbial carbohydrates and lipoproteins (Option B) • C-type lectin receptors (CLR)- detect mannose residues • Cytoplasmic (intracellular) PRRs: 41 
Sold by @itachibot • Nucleotide oligomerization (NOD)-like receptors (NLR) - NOD1 and NOD2 - Detects bacterial 
cell wall peptidoglycans (Option A) • RIG-I-like receptors (RLRs) - detect viral RNA (Option C) • Secreted PRRs On the contrary, BMP receptors are multifunctional transmembrane serine-threonine kinase 
receptors that belong to the transforming growth factor  (TGF-) superfamily, regulating cell 
growth, differentiation, and apoptosis with no role in pattern recognition. Also, there are no 
receptors termed "BMP-like receptors". Note: A mutation in the Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2) gene enhances the 
proliferation and reduces the apoptosis of pulmonary vascular endothelial and smooth muscle 
cells, leading to hereditary pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

questions.question:
Question 5: A 23-year-old presents with diarrhea, fever, and vomiting. The given bacteria is implicated. 
Which toll-like receptor binds to the structure of the bacteria marked A?
questions.explanation:
The given image and clinical history suggest a typhoid infection. The structure marked A is the 
flagella of bacteria. Toll-like receptor (TLR) 5 binds to the flagella of bacteria. Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are transmembrane receptors that have an extracellular domain, that 
detect infecting pathogens. • TLR 1 - Mycobacteria and Gram-negative bacteria • TLR 2 - Mycobacteria and Gram-positive bacteria • TLR 3 - Viral RNA • TLR 4 - Gram-negative bacteria • TLR 5 - Flagella • TLR 9 - Bacterial DNA, some herpes viruses, malarial parasite TLRs act through the NF-KB pathway and initiate inflammation.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 28-year-old woman presents with a fever of 103°F, hypotension, confusion, and a diffuse 
rash as shown below. 3 days back, she had uncontrollable epistaxis for which a nasal pack 
was placed. What is the likely mechanism of action of the microbial toxin that has caused her 
current illness?
questions.explanation:
This woman presented with fever, hypotension, and a diffuse erythematous rash, three days after 
a nasal packing was done. This is characteristic of toxic shock syndrome - commonly caused by 
staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which is a superantigen. Superantigens act by causing polyclonal activation of T cells. They activate a large number of T 
cells irrespective of their antigen specificity. In contrast to regular antigens which bind to the binding groove on T cells, superantigens bind 
outside the groove directly to the lateral aspect of the TCR  chain. This leads to a massive release 
of cytokines and polyclonal activation of T cells. Clinically, this manifests as fever, hypotension, and skin exfoliation. Examples of organisms that produce superantigens: • Bacterial 43 
Sold by @itachibot • Staphylococcus aureus- Enterotoxins • Group A streptococci - Pyrogenic exotoxin • Mycoplasma arthritidis- mitogen 1 • Yersinia enterocolitica • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis • Viral • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) • Rabies nucleocapsid • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor. • Fungal- Malassezia furfur

questions.question: Question 8: What are the changes in the variable regions of an immunoglobulin known as?
questions.explanation:
Changes in the variable regions of heavy and light chains of an immunoglobulin are called an 
idiotype. Other options: Option B: Isotypes are the changes in the constant regions of the heavy chain of the 
immunoglobulin. Option C: Allotypes refer to multiple alleles that exist for some genes. This leads to subtle amino 
acid differences that occur in some but not all members of the same species. Option D: An epitope is the smallest unit of antigenicity and it is an antigenic determinant.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following statements about immunoglobulins is false? 32 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: IgG is used to diagnose fetal infection

questions.explanation:
IgG cannot detect fetal infections because it is not produced by the fetus in significant amounts. IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and 
provides natural passive immunity to the newborn.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following immunoglobulins acts as surface immunoglobulin on B cells?
questions.explanation:
Monomeric IgM is the major antibody receptor on the surface of B lymphocytes for antigen 
recognition. IgD is the other class of antibodies which acts as the B cell receptors. 44 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of repeated sinopulmonary infections caused by 
encapsulated organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this case?
questions.explanation:
Deficiency of IgG2 results in recurrent sinopulmonary infections with encapsulated organisms. IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and 
provides natural passive immunity to the newborn. IgG1 is the antibody maximally transported 
across the placenta, whereas IgG2 has the least transplacental movement. Deficiencies of other IgG: • IgG1- bacterial infections (diphtheria, tetanus)(Option A) • IgG3- viral infections (Option C) • IgG4- parasitic infections (Option D)

questions.question:
Question 12: Identify the class of immunoglobulin■ shown in the image below. 33 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA. IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are 
usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions 
such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts. When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it 
exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two 
additional polypeptides: • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule. • Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the 
epithelial cell. 45 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which immunoglobulin is majorly responsible for the reaction demonstrated below?
questions.explanation:
The image shows blood typing, which works on the principle of agglutination. IgM is mainly 
responsible for agglutination. It is the most efficient immunoglobulin in agglutination, complement fixation, and other antigen–
antibody reactions and is important also in defense against bacteria and viruses. It is a pentamer, and hence is more effective than IgG in opsonization (C3b mediated), 
bactericidal action and bacterial agglutination but less effective in neutralization of toxins and

questions.question:
Question 14: You are counseling a new mother about the importance of breastfeeding. What forms the 
secretory component of the antibody that is maximally present in breast milk?

options.b: Epithelial cells of lining mucosa only

questions.explanation:
The antibody maximally present in breast milk is IgA. The secretory component of IgA is formed 
by epithelial cells of lining mucosa. IgA occurs in two forms- serum IgA (monomer) and secretory IgA. Secretory IgA is a dimer formed by two monomer units joined together by a J-chain and 
a secretory component (secretory piece). Secretory IgA along with the J chain is synthesized by 
the plasma cells situated near the mucosal or glandular epithelium. The secretory component is 
synthesized by epithelial cells, not by plasma cells. It is believed to protect IgA from denaturation by bacterial proteases. 46 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end 
products?
questions.explanation:
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab 
fragments. Enzymatic digestion of antibody: • Papain- 2 Fab fragments and one Fc fragment • Pepsin- One F(ab’)2 fragment and many smaller fragments • Mercaptoethanol- 2 H and 2 L chains 47 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Affinity maturation is due to:
questions.explanation:
Affinity maturation is due to somatic hypermutation. Affinity maturation is the process by which antibodies gain increased affinity, avidity, and 
anti-pathogen activity. It is a result of somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in 
B cells, coupled to selection for antigen binding. This process occurs in the germinal centers and proceeds for weeks after acute infection or 
vaccination, or for many cycles during chronic infection. The resulting antibodies can be highly 
mutated from their germline-encoded counterparts, with increases of several orders of magnitude 
in affinity for antigen compared to the corresponding naïve B cell receptors (BCRs). Other options: Option A: Isotype switching, also known as class switch recombination, is a process where the 
constant region of the antibody heavy chain is changed, leading to a switch in the antibody isotype 
(e.g., from IgM to IgG). This process is crucial for the functional properties of antibodies but is not 
directly involved in affinity maturation. Option C: mRNA splicing is a cellular process that involves the removal of introns and the joining 
of exons to generate mature mRNA. While this process is essential for the production of 
functional antibodies, it is not specifically associated with affinity maturation. Affinity maturation 
primarily occurs through somatic hypermutation. Option D: VDJ rearrangement is the process by which the variable regions of immunoglobulin 
genes are assembled from gene segments (V, D, and J segments). This process contributes to the 
diversity of antibodies but is distinct from affinity maturation. Affinity maturation occurs after 
VDJ rearrangement and is driven by somatic hypermutation in the variable regions.

questions.question:
Question 17: An immunologist is conducting an experiment to understand precipitation reactions. He 
notes that on adding excessive amount of antigen to a serum sample containing small amount 
of antibodies, the amount of precipitate formed is less, compared to adding smaller amount 35 
Sold by @itachibot of antigen to the same sample. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.explanation:
48 
Sold by @itachibot This phenomenon is called post–zone phenomenon because it has excessive antigen in the test 
system, leading to weak or even absent precipitation. Lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly 
influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. • Prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent 
precipitation- false-negative test) • Zone of equivalence- antigen, and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum 
precipitation occurs. • Post–zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. 
(weaker/absent precipitation) Flocculation: Instead of sedimenting, precipitate remains suspended as floculus.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient presented to the casualty with the following finding. A positive Nagler's reaction 
confirmed the presence of lecithinase-producing organisms. What is the principle behind this 
test?
questions.explanation:
Nagler’s reaction is an example of a neutralization test. It is done for the detection of 
lecithinase toxin produced by C. perfringens. The alpha-toxin of C. perfringens has phospholipase activity. When grown on a medium 
containing egg yolk phospholipid, an area of opacity around the bacterial colonies is seen (Nagler's 
positive). The presence of antitoxin can inhibit this. Other examples of neutralization tests are: • Plaque inhibition test- neutralization of bacteriophages • Schick test- neutralization of diphtheria toxin by antitoxin • Anti-streptolysin O test- for beta-hemolytic Streptococci. 51 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient presents with a painless ulcer on his penis. A Wasserman test is done and is 
reactive. What is the principle of this test?
questions.explanation:
Wassermann's reaction is an example of a complement fixation test. It is a non-specific test for the 
diagnosis of syphilis. An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the 
antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the 
use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following activates the classical complement pathway?
questions.explanation:
The classical pathway of complement is activated by immune complexes or antigen-antibody 
complexes. (antigen bound to IgM or IgG). Lipopolysaccharide of gram-negative bacteria activates the alternative complement pathway. The binding of mannose-binding lectin to mannose residues (on the surfaces of Salmonella, 
Neisseria, and Listeria) activates the lectin complement pathway. 52 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: In the alternate complement pathway, which of the following functions as C3 convertase?
questions.explanation: C3 convertase in the alternate pathway is C3bBb. In the classical pathway and lectin pathway, the C3 convertase is C4b2a.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 23-year-old girl presents with the finding shown below. She has a history of multiple 
similar episodes in the past and reports that some of her family members have similar 
complaints. She has no itching. Which of the following is deficient in this patient? 37 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This girl presents with features of hereditary angioneurotic edema, which is due to a deficiency of 
C1 inhibitor. Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder that is more common than 
complement deficiency states. A deficiency of C1 inhibitor leads 53 
Sold by @itachibot to unregulated activation of kallikrein. This increases the production of vasoactive peptides such 
as bradykinin. It causes episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the 
larynx and the gastrointestinal tract. This may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, 
vomiting, and diarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress. Note - • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - collagen vascular disorders. • C5-C8 deficiency - recurrent bacteremia with Neisseria 54 
Sold by @itachibot Structure and Functions of the Immune System & Immune Response
